Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Young Leader Project
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will provide children ages 7-11 years with an interactive learning program that cultivates core leadership skills. This project goes deeper than many traditional socio-emotional programs by fortifying children with the behavioral skills and mindset they need to evolve as effective leaders. The educational curriculum was developed by psychologists who specialize in leadership development, and is based on cutting-edge child developmental, leadership, and educational research. This project aims to research the engagement and effectiveness of the program and its ability to enhance ten core leadership behaviors in youth, at home, in the community, and in academic settings. This program has the potential to make a long-term impact on the next generation of youth, promoting resilience in the face of adverse events, such as school violence and cyberbullying, and to positively shape the next generation of leaders, helping them form lifelong commitments to personal and professional development. The project has philanthropic aspirations to make the educational curriculum available to all children and schools, regardless of socio-economic standing, supporting the mission of NSF to promote the health, prosperity and welfare of the nation through science.


This project is focused on the development of an interactive leadership program for children, that is proven to make a positive impact on leadership behaviors and that is also fun and engaging for youth and their adult caregivers and educators. What sets this program apart from others is that the research will provide evidence that the program builds the critical skills it intends on developing in children. The program is designed to be self-led or facilitated by an adult caregiver or educator, either using an online platform or physical materials. As children move from one leadership competency to another, they are extrinsically and intrinsically rewarded for their efforts. Adult caregivers and educators are encouraged to participate and are provided mastery building exercises that help them take the child?s leadership understanding and skill to the next level. A database has been developed to track real-time participant feedback as curriculum elements are developed. The testing of educational content will focus on three aspects, which include maximizing content appropriateness, validating learning and skill retention, and assessing variances and preferences for mode of delivery. Results will be used to make modifications to the curriculum and product design for commercialization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Children live in a new and violent reality; experiencing school shootings, bullying on social media, youth suicide, and mental health issues at increasingly alarming rates. Programs targeting leadership, social, and emotional skill development are needed more than ever to address the unique experiences of children today. Developing these vital skills becomes especially important as children become young adults, expected to excel, when they enter the workforce. The mission of Young Leader Project (YLP) is to positively shape the next generation by improving their resilience to negative influences by promoting a commitment to positive, prosocial behaviors. 

YLP develops prosocial skills by leveraging technology, gameplay, and stealth learning, paired with caregiver development and resources, to help children develop skills, such as self-awareness, mindfulness, and resilience. The YLP content is curated by a team of psychologists, with expertise in leadership, using evidence-based practices from the fields of psychology, business, education and human development. YLP is built for children ages 7-11, and their guardians, because it is during this critical developmental period that cognitive abilities shift from concrete to reflective, causing children to explore their impact on the world around them. 

YLP is innovating the edtech and game industries by creating a fun, story- and quest-driven game that disguises impactful and deep learning of leadership, social, and emotional skills. To do this, the YLP psychology and learning team is collaborating with game designers who have developed games for some of the largest child brands in the world. Parents are also encouraged to participate and learn alongside their child, via the comprehensive Young Leader Portal that includes resources and bonus activities to do with the family. YLP also includes the Leader Tracker, an assessment built by the YLP team and linked to learning objectives, to measure progress throughout the game. The goal is to establish daily habits, among all children and their parents, that sets the stage for a lifelong commitment to prosocial behaviors. 

But we did not arrive at these innovations alone. During Phase I, the team collected data from 155 parents, 43 educators, 123 children ages 7-11, 40 caregiver-child dyads (n = 40 caregivers and 40 children), and 30 EdTech experts and tech product advisors. 

Prior to Phase I, the team developed 130+ activities linked to 21 leadership, social, and emotional competencies linked to long-term interpersonal and professional success, as well as the first version of the tracking assessment. Several activities from 4 competencies were developed into the first YLP prototype.

As a result, the team began Phase I with a prototype of the YLP program, consisting of workbooks, a learning management system, and a hybrid of the two. Results from these tests showed we needed to go the digital route, that learning needed to be disguised, and that parents wanted to be involved in the learning process. Caregivers reported appreciating the fact that activities increased their own personal understanding and comfort in building skills with their children. Caregivers also voiced the need for an assessment that could track changes in behavior. Overall, the results showed that the content was relevant and engaging to children and parents, evidenced by continued use of the skills and language introduced during prototype testing during post-interviews.

Based on these results, the team iterated the YLP content to be delivered via a digital platform, specifically a mobile app. To do this, the team integrated story-telling and game design, combining these to make the content more impactful and engaging for children. The team tested three (of 21) YLP competencies using this method by developing a mobile app prototype. Results showed an increase in engagement and retention of skills, assessed with an in-game assessment and interviews. In fact, 75% of participants said they would play YLP at home. 

Results from the second round of prototype testing validated the team's story-driven, gamified approach to content delivery and engaging children in learning vital prosocial skills. The team hired an expert game design company to fill this gap in the team's knowledge and began research and development on a third YLP game prototype and Young Leader Portal, which houses parent resources and progress tracking tools. 

Further research and development, post Phase I, will focus on ensuring there is learning and engagement as the remainder of the stealth learning game, and associated resources, is developed. Once fully developed, YLP intends to develop a sponsored program that provides these resources to low income families.
